North Carolina: s photo ID law provides options for compliance, such as filling out a "Reasonable Impediment Declaration Form" if a voter does not have a photo ID.
The NCSL classifies North Carolina: s photo ID law as "non-strict," meaning it offers voters more than one way to cast their ballot without showing photo ID.
Compared to other photo ID laws: North Carolina's law is considered lenient, but not compared to the 18 states with ID laws that don't require a photo ID.
